messages.msgSnippet: Bob, No I m the one whos only a few stops away from Machida I m in Sobudai-Mae which is on only two stops away from Machida by train. What s his phone number
messages.messageBody:
Bob,

No I'm the one whos only a few stops away from Machida
I'm in Sobudai-Mae which is on only two stops away
from Machida by train. What's his phone number I'll
give him a call this weekend as it's time for another
meeting this weekend. If he wants I'll meet him in
Machida and take him to meet Gordon at the meeting or
wherever we are meeting for lunch. Gordon are we
meeting at the regular place for lunch this weekend??

Bob R

Jim

Rich,

I would say -Gimei-.

I used Wakayama (Vol.1). To my eye, not that close of
a match, with a few odd & random strokes.
My confidence interval isn't high. Just thought it
a good exercise. I defer to more veteran opinions, but
figured I would take the first step.

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Matt, I agree with you and Gordon on the quality, which isn t very good even without considering the asking price.  You could buy a fairly nice tsuba with that
messages.messageBody:
Matt,
I agree with you and Gordon on the quality, which isn't very good even without considering the asking price. You could buy a fairly nice tsuba with that money. There's a Nobuyoshi that worked in Edo, born in 1807 and died in 1878. Some of his signatures are illustrated in Wakayama, but I notice that the listing isn't up on the site any longer and I didn't compare them when I had the chance.

Jim

Although I know nothing about anything really, I think it is pretty
obvious that this piece does not have anywhere near the quality to
warrant such a high price...... Opinions?

Matt

It is interesting that the paper looks like a dealer's paper and there
is no actual discussion of the tsuba anywhere on the page. Looks like
someone scamming. It is not even that good of a tsuba. I am not familiar
with this maker, perhaps Jim can shed some light on that.

Gordon

No, Machida is a little further away than that, but he can come into town
next Saturday and go to the NTHK's study meeting. Give him my e-mail address
and I will set him up. Always good to hear from you. Any future Japan trips
in the works? Any chance of you making Chicago in September?



Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba //  Cupped Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Peter, I do not know if I have met Mr. Lissenden. By chance, is this person a fencing coach on the West Coast? I ve also had similar thoughts about some of
messages.messageBody:
Peter,

I do not know if I have met Mr. Lissenden. By chance,
is this person a fencing coach on the West Coast?

I've also had similar thoughts about some of rapier
tsuba being more the smallsword form copies of the
18th century. I was not sure how far back such
smallswords were made and used. From mental trivia, I
remebered record of one used in a duel c. 1715.

My knowledge of western sword types is erratic, so I
don't put up much arguement about what was first made
when.
Sailors of all types (English, Dutch, Portugese,
Spanish... southern Spanish and Portugese of mixed
Moorish ancestry) carried weapons of all types. I
wondered about cutlasses and other weapons. Shipdeck
weapons made for hacking with little or no knowledge
of fencing.

The study tsuba I have was worn carved face towards
the blade, with the cupping toward the hand. Most
interesting to me, the INSIDE of the cup was once
entirely covered in zogan of gold or silver. It is a
fist sized tsuba, so that was a rather flashy display
to anyone looking at the samurai who carried it.
I did not realize this when I first received it.
Only when it was pointed out to me by Jim Gilbert. I
can only wonder if it were patterned, and what the
entire rig must have looked like.
Someone quite intentionally dug most of the gold or
silver out of the cup, leaving small scars. A shame.

Curran


> Curran,
> I sure won't promise any "depth" on this issue. I
> also don't know which
> book you have in mind, but I happen to have
> Yoshimura's "Namban Tsuba:
> Akogare No Dezain" with me here. It shows NO cupped
> guards at all... which
> merely means they don't fit his classification.
> I suppose that cupped guards could be reflective of
> European designs, but
> it seems to be no more than a very general
> reference. Furthermore, I have
> become convince by John Lissenden that most Namban
> "rapier" guards date to
> the 18th century. In John's view the classic
> "rapier" tsuba appear to be
> copies not of rapiers but of the later smallsword
> form - which is a
> development of the 18th century. Cuphilt rapiers, on
> the other hand, are
> (supposedly!) Spanish and 17th century. Given how
> things were in Japan at
> that time, I wonder how common they could have been
> in Japan. Maybe, of
> course, that could explain how the samurai could
> have got the cup pointing
> in the wrong direction!
> Peter
>
> _
>
_____________________________________________________

> There is a Namban tsuba book out there. Paperback.
> We
> requested Bob Orssman look for it, but he could not
> find it. It is supposedly a $25 book, and not very
> old.
>
> I do not recall much in the way of cupped guards.
> Could you please give your opinion against the
> cupped guards being not attributed to westerd style?
> I've heard 2 arguments against it, but not in much
> depth.

> The one I recently picked up is more of a bowl shape
> (more of an L edge to it, but about 1 cm deep), and
> would have been worn correctly cupped towards the
> hand.
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba //  Cupped Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Phil et al- Remember that the tsuba is a hand stop and not a handguard. Thus the more ornate of the two sides is worn OUT when the sword is in the scabbard.
messages.messageBody:
Phil et al-
Remember that the tsuba is a hand stop and not a handguard.
Thus the more ornate of the two sides is worn "OUT" when the sword is
in the scabbard. Once the sword is drawn it is just a hand stop (or
guard) but all decoration ceases to have any meaning. With few
exceptions the most work is applied to outside of the "cup", which if
you think about it is most aesthetically pleasing...
-t

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba //  Cupped Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Peter- There is a Namban tsuba book out there. Paperback. We requested Bob Orssman look for it, but he could not find it. It is supposedly a $25 book, and not
messages.messageBody:
Peter-

There is a Namban tsuba book out there. Paperback. We
requested Bob Orssman look for it, but he could not
find it. It is supposedly a $25 book, and not very
old.
Jim G. purchased it from a book dealer. In it there
are some outstanding rapier style examples, including
near matching western pieces upon which they may have
been based.

I do not recall much in the way of cupped guards.
Could you please give your opinion against the
cupped guards being not attributed to westerd style?
I've heard 2 arguments against it, but not in much
depth.

As i mentioned, many of the tsuba 'cup' the wrong way.
The one I recently picked up is more of a bowl shape
(more of an L edge to it, but about 1 cm deep), and
would have been worn correctly cupped towards the
hand.

Curran


Curran,
I sure won't promise any "depth" on this issue. I also don't know which
book you have in mind, but I happen to have Yoshimura's "Namban Tsuba:
Akogare No Dezain" with me here. It shows NO cupped guards at all... which
merely means they don't fit his classification.
I suppose that cupped guards could be reflective of European designs, but
it seems to be no more than a very general reference. Furthermore, I have
become convince by John Lissenden that most Namban "rapier" guards date to
the 18th century. In John's view the classic "rapier" tsuba appear to be
copies not of rapiers but of the later smallsword form - which is a
development of the 18th century. Cuphilt rapiers, on the other hand, are
(supposedly!) Spanish and 17th century. Given how things were in Japan at
that time, I wonder how common they could have been in Japan. Maybe, of
course, that could explain how the samurai could have got the cup pointing
in the wrong direction!
Peter

_

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba //  Cupped Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Peter- There is a Namban tsuba book out there. Paperback. We requested Bob Orssman look for it, but he could not find it. It is supposedly a $25 book, and not
messages.messageBody:
Peter-

There is a Namban tsuba book out there. Paperback. We
requested Bob Orssman look for it, but he could not
find it. It is supposedly a $25 book, and not very
old.
Jim G. purchased it from a book dealer. In it there
are some outstanding rapier style examples, including
near matching western pieces upon which they may have
been based.

I do not recall much in the way of cupped guards.
Could you please give your opinion against the
cupped guards being not attributed to westerd style?
I've heard 2 arguments against it, but not in much
depth.

As i mentioned, many of the tsuba 'cup' the wrong way.
The one I recently picked up is more of a bowl shape
(more of an L edge to it, but about 1 cm deep), and
would have been worn correctly cupped towards the
hand.

Curran



--- Peter A Bleed <pbleed1@...> wrote:
>
> Friends,
> I have become rather interested in Namban tsuba that
> are made to look like
> rapier guards. They are pretty rare and I own only a
> couple and have seen
> only a few others. In that regard, I have liked
> looking at other Namban
> tsuba and cupped guards. All that to say this is an
> interesting thread.
> John, I'd love to see your rapier style guard if you
> can post a pic.
> Let me say, however, that I am not certain about
> the link between cupped
> tsuba and European swords. I have seen a number of
> cupped tsuba that I
> suppose could be inspired by European cuphilts, but
> may of these look like
> they are Hizen style rather than "Namban" (whatever
> that is). Furthermore,
> in the case of the tsuba that got this conversation
> started, it looks to me
> like the cup would have pointed TOWARD the blade!
> Pretty different from the
> European cuphilt style.
> Peter
>
>
>
> Peter Bleed
> Associate Dean
> College of Arts and Sciences
> 1223 Oldfather Hall
> University of Nebraska
> Lincoln, NE 68588-0312
> (402) 472-2891

>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: I have a cupped tsuba by Tanshu Sadamasa, it has the Yoshino design with blossom riveted to the plate, it is also signed with Fujiwara which as far as I know
messages.messageBody:
I have a cupped tsuba by Tanshu Sadamasa, it has the Yoshino design with
blossom riveted to the plate, it is also signed with 'Fujiwara' which as far
as I know he did not use with his other tsuba. There is a very similar tsuba
in 'Hyaku-tan'.
Alan

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba //  Cupped Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Friends, I have become rather interested in Namban tsuba that are made to look like rapier guards. They are pretty rare and I own only a couple and have seen
messages.messageBody:
Friends,
I have become rather interested in Namban tsuba that are made to look like
rapier guards. They are pretty rare and I own only a couple and have seen
only a few others. In that regard, I have liked looking at other Namban
tsuba and cupped guards. All that to say this is an interesting thread.
John, I'd love to see your rapier style guard if you can post a pic.
Let me say, however, that I am not certain about the link between cupped
tsuba and European swords. I have seen a number of cupped tsuba that I
suppose could be inspired by European cuphilts, but may of these look like
they are Hizen style rather than "Namban" (whatever that is). Furthermore,
in the case of the tsuba that got this conversation started, it looks to me
like the cup would have pointed TOWARD the blade! Pretty different from the
European cuphilt style.
Peter



Peter Bleed
Associate Dean
College of Arts and Sciences
1223 Oldfather Hall
University of Nebraska
Lincoln, NE 68588-0312
(402) 472-2891

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba //  Cupped Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Rich- I ve been taught the same as John Berta said. I recently traded for a damaged one that is more interesting in some ways (larger, deeper, more definitely
messages.messageBody:
Rich-

I've been taught the same as John Berta said.
I recently traded for a damaged one that is more
interesting in some ways (larger, deeper, more
definitely Namban: 2 dragons chasing the flaming
jewel) but in worse condition.
I don't see many examples and wanted one. There
were 3 or 4 at the San Fran show, including a very
plain-jane daisho set and a nice one minty clean
sukashi one -property of Cary. I believe Cary's was
from a non Kyushu province (?) showing migration of
the foreign style. I could be wrong.

Price on this one isn't too bad, but shipper doesn't
do foreign shipping.

As Jim G. may mention if back on list yet, the
Japanese supposedly wore them "the wrong way" with the
cup down like an umbrella over the scabbard mouth.

Curran

>
> These tsuba were made in the style of the guards on
> the Portuguese rapiers. I have seen a few and have
> one I think.
>
> This one is decorated nicer than any I have handled.
> Most are just plain iron.
>
> John

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich; These tsuba were made in the style of the guards on the Portuguese rapiers.  I have seen a few and have one I think. This one is decorated nicer than
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich;

These tsuba were made in the style of the guards on the Portuguese rapiers. I have seen a few and have one I think.

This one is decorated nicer than any I have handled. Most are just plain iron.

John
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy
Sent: Friday, October 03, 2003 3:10 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Tsuba


Anyone know what this is, it is something I have not seen before.

http://page6.auctions.yahoo.co.jp/jp/auction/f8461627

Rich

messages.messageBody:
I recall seeing one on that gorgeous Juyo Norishige that was sold by Mr.
Condell.

http://ikkyudo.com/gallery/cat/xsx1.htm

Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: alchemyst [mailto:alchemyst@...]
Verzonden: vrijdag 3 oktober 2003 13:47
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba


--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Richard Turner" <ikkanshi@w...>
wrote:
> Anyone know what this is, it is something I have not seen before.
>
> http://page6.auctions.yahoo.co.jp/jp/auction/f8461627
>
> Rich


Rich -

A cupped tsuba, probably Myochin, Umetada or Shoami.
Likely early-mid Edo period. While not common, they
are not really all that unusual either.

Rich S
